newsitem.title: VENEZUELA: Venezuela sticks to plan despite oil bonanza.
newsitem.headline: Venezuela sticks to plan despite oil bonanza.

text.p: The Venezuelan government will stick to its economic adjustment program in spite of the windfall of unexpected revenues thanks to a recent rise in oil prices, Planning Minister Teodoro Petkoff said Friday.
"The adjustment program will continue even if oil rises to a $1,000 per barrel," the colorful minister told reporters after a meeting with cabinet colleagues.

Venezuelan oil export prices have climbed to a five-year high of $20.40 per barrel following U.S. military intervention in Iraq last week. Government officials have said the higher-than-expected oil prices will bring in more than $2.5 billion in unbudgeted revenues.
Petkoff, who fought against the government as a communist guerrilla in the 1960s, said the government was more concerned about the non-oil sector of the economy.
"It is obvious that the oil sector is going to grow more than was expected, but we are more interested in the non-oil sector where there will be no revision," he said.
The non-oil sector will contract in 1996 before recovering next year, Petkoff said. He gave no specific figures.
"Economic growth will come next year just as was expected before (U.S. President Bill) Clinton began bombing (Iraqi President Saddam) Hussein.

"Everything to do with structural and institutional reforms, the privatization program, the restructuring of the state, reform to severance payments, all this continues as if Clinton were not doing anything," Petkoff added.
